goal:
The "Tier?rztliche Vereinigung f?r Tierschutz e.V." (TVT) was established in 1985 and currently has approx. 1,300 members, all of them veterinarians.
The members come from all over Germany and from all areas of veterinary activity, including small animal and farm animal practitioners, state veterinary officers, university researchers and lecturers, zoo and industry veterinarians. Our members feel they have a special responsibility to promote independent, professional, effective and scientifically validated advice on animal protection. Currently, the TVT is the only veterinarian organisation for animal welfare in Europe.

The TVT provides general information on species-appropriate animal husbandry and deals with all current issues concerning the production and care of domestic animals.
The association has working groups that specialise in different areas of animal welfare. There are currently 10 working groups: cats and dogs, other small domestic animals, farm animals/livestock, animals in social services, horses, stunning and slaughtering, laboratory animals, trade and transport, wild animals and hunting, as well as circus and zoo animals.
These working groups put together information sheets and issue statements on topical issues relevant to animal welfare. The information, statements and guidelines issued by TVT are always based on ethical considerations, scientific knowledge and practical experience. The more than 150 TVT Guidelines on animal welfare areas not or vaguely clarified by laws are nation-wide used in courts, by lawyers, attorneys and official veterinarians. All publications are available for download at www.tierschutz-tvt.de.
The members of the TVT work in animal welfare commissions and animal welfare advisory councils, inform and advise colleagues, veterinary authorities and animal welfare organisations and use public relation activities to influence discussions and the development of legislation. In addition, the association informs and advises animal owners and public authorities and closely collaborates with other veterinary associations and animal welfare organisations.
